questions.text: A 20-year primi presented at 32 weeks with eclampsia. She was started on MgSO4 (Pritchard’s regime) and she delivered after induction of labor. Maintenance dose of MgSO4 was continued for 24 hours. Prevention of Mg toxicity involves monitoring of the following clinical parameters:

options.label: A
options.text: Deep tendon reflexes, urine output, Respiratory rate

options.label: B
options.text: Deep tendon reflexes, O2 saturation, consciousness status

options.label: C
options.text: O2 saturation, urine output, heart rate

options.label: D
options.text: Heart rate, BP, respiratory rate and urine output

questions.correct_answer: A. Deep tendon reflexes, urine output, Respiratory rate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Deep tendon reflexes, urine output, Respiratory rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The prevention of magnesium toxicity in the management of eclampsia involves careful monitoring of deep tendon reflexes, urine output, and respiratory rate. Deep tendon reflexes help detect early signs of toxicity, urine output indicates renal function and magnesium clearance, and respiratory rate assesses potential respiratory depression from magnesium sulfate.
  • ➤ Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1 st edition
  • ➤ Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1 st edition

questions.text: A 22-year Primigravida presents at 34 weeks to the emergency with a BP of 160/110 mmHg. Her urine albumin is 3 +. She is complaining of headache and blurring of vision. On examination, the fetal heart cannot be auscultated. The uterus is relaxed, and a vaginal examination reveals a soft cervix which is 1 cm dilated and 30% effaced. You administer IV labetalol to lower her BP. What is the best immediate next line of management?

options.label: D
options.text: Urgent Ultrasound to see the fetal status

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Prophylactic MgSO4

questions.text: Patellar reflexes disappear when the plasma magnesium level reaches:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 10 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Monitoring for magnesium toxicity is crucial when administering magnesium sulfate, especially in obstetric settings for conditions like preeclampsia or eclampsia. The loss of deep tendon reflexes, such as the patellar reflex, is the first clinical sign and usually occurs at plasma magnesium levels around 10 mEq/L.
  • ➤ Monitoring for magnesium toxicity is crucial when administering magnesium sulfate, especially in obstetric settings for conditions like preeclampsia or eclampsia.
  • ➤ The loss of deep tendon reflexes, such as the patellar reflex, is the first clinical sign and usually occurs at plasma magnesium levels around 10 mEq/L.

questions.text: Anti-hypertensives contra-indicated in pregnancy are all except?
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The anti-hypertensive drug of choice in pregnancy is labetalol Alpha-methyldopa is considered safe and is one of the preferred anti hypertensives in pregnancy. However, ACE inhibitors (like captopril and enalapril) and ARBs (like losartan) are contraindicated due to their potential adverse effects on the developing fetus.

questions.text: All are regimes of MgSO4 for treatment of eclampsia except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Magpie regime

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The key educational takeaway is that while there are several recognized regimens for the administration of magnesium sulfate in the management of eclampsia (like the Dhaka, Sibai, and Zuspan regimens), the "Magpie regime" is not one of them. Instead, the Magpie Trial was a significant research study that helped establish the effectiveness of magnesium sulfate in this context.

questions.text: A 36-year primigravida presents with seizures to the emergency. On examination, she is 36 weeks pregnant with BP 150/100mmHg. She is given loading dose of MGSO4 as per Pritchards regime but has another seizure. Which of the following should be done next?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Additional magnesium sulphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Short acting benzodiazepines like midazolam may be used to control the ongoing seizure. Consider thiopental if the seizures are refractory. Ensure that the patient is also receiving the maintenance dose of magnesium sulfate to prevent further seizures.
  • ➤ Short acting benzodiazepines like midazolam may be used to control the ongoing seizure.
  • ➤ Consider thiopental if the seizures are refractory.
  • ➤ Ensure that the patient is also receiving the maintenance dose of magnesium sulfate to prevent further seizures.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1862, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1862, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Preeclampsia is a marker for all of the following morbidities later in life except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ LONG TERM CONSEQUENCES ASSOCIATED WITH PREECLAMPSIA:
  • ➤ LONG TERM CONSEQUENCES ASSOCIATED WITH PREECLAMPSIA:
  • ➤ The earlier preeclampsia is diagnosed during the index pregnancy, the greater the likelihood of recurrence. Nulliparous diagnosed with preeclampsia before 30 weeks have a recurrence risk as high as 40 percent during a subsequent pregnancy. Women with HELLP have risk of 5 to 26 percent risk of recurrence in subsequent pregnancy 20 percent of preeclampsia women had hypertension at interval of 2 years. Ischemic heart disease Stroke Increased risk of chronic hypertension and diabetes and even metabolic syndrome 4-fold increased risk of chronic renal disease Increased risk of impaired cognitive functioning and lower vision related quality of life
  • ➤ The earlier preeclampsia is diagnosed during the index pregnancy, the greater the likelihood of recurrence. Nulliparous diagnosed with preeclampsia before 30 weeks have a recurrence risk as high as 40 percent during a subsequent pregnancy.

  • ➤ Features of Magnesium Toxicity:
  • ➤ Features of Magnesium Toxicity:
  • ➤ Loss of deep tendon reflex (Depression of patellar reflex is the earliest sign of patellar toxicity): Earliest Sign Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per minute) Chest pain, heart block, pulmonary edema Cardiac arrest O 2 saturation monitoring (PaO2 < 95%) Double vision Slurred speech Nausea-vomiting Muscular weakness
  • ➤ Loss of deep tendon reflex (Depression of patellar reflex is the earliest sign of patellar toxicity): Earliest Sign

  • ➤ Muscular weakness

questions.text: During a routine antenatal visit, an 24-year G1 at 20 weeks gestational age undergoes a urinalysis. The dipstick done indicates the presence of glycosuria. options.label: C
options.text: The patient’s urinalysis is consistent with normal pregnancy

options.text: The patient’s urine sample is contaminated.

It is essential to consider other factors, such as diabetes, urinary tract infections, and sample contamination, and perform further tests if necessary to determine the cause of glycosuria.

questions.text: Pederson’s hypothesis states that:

options.label: A
options.text: Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia resulting in fetal hyperinsulinemia and related complications

options.label: B
options.text: Maternal insulin can cross the placenta resulting in neonatal hypoglycemia

options.label: C
options.text: Maternal hyperglycemia results in an increased incidence of congenital anomalies

options.label: D
options.text: Fetal hyperinsulinemia results in a lower incidence of respiratory distress syndrome

questions.correct_answer: A. Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia resulting in fetal hyperinsulinemia and related complications
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia resulting in fetal hyperinsulinemia and related complications.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Pederson's hypothesis emphasizes the direct impact of maternal hyperglycemia on the fetus, leading to fetal hyperglycemia and resultant fetal hyperinsulinemia. This cascade underscores the importance of strict glycemic control in pregnant women with diabetes to prevent fetal complications, including macrosomia, birth injuries, and neonatal hypoglycemia.
  • ➤ Pederson's hypothesis emphasizes the direct impact of maternal hyperglycemia on the fetus, leading to fetal hyperglycemia and resultant fetal hyperinsulinemia.
  • ➤ This cascade underscores the importance of strict glycemic control in pregnant women with diabetes to prevent fetal complications, including macrosomia, birth injuries, and neonatal hypoglycemia.

questions.explanation:

The lower threshold for diabetic women is due to the increased risk of macrosomia and related birth complications, including shoulder dystocia.

Ans. C. 3%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Considering, the slow progress i.e. less than 1% per annum in reduction of anaemia from 2005 to 2015, the Government of India has launched the Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) strategy under the Prime Minister’s Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment (POSHAN) Abhiyaan and the targets has been set to reduce anaemia by 3% per year. This program has a 6x6x6 strategy under AMB i.e. Six age groups Six interventions and Six institutional mechanisms

questions.text: A 20 y G2P1 presents at 36 weeks in labor. On examination she has pallor. Her PR is 90/min and BP is 110/70 mmHg. Her Hb is 4g%. Which of the following should be done in the 2 nd stage of labor?

options.label: A
options.text: Cut short the 2 nd stage with forceps.

options.label: B
options.text: Cut short the 2 nd stage with vacuum

questions.correct_answer: A. Cut short the 2 nd stage with forceps.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Cut short the 2ndstage with forceps.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Precuation to be taken in 2 nd stage of labor in a patient with severe anemia Cut short with forceps (Especially in this scenario as she is preterm – vacuum is contraindicated in preterm. Also, forceps is preferred in scenarios where the woman should not bear down as vacuum requires additional bearing down efforts).
  • ➤ Precuation to be taken in 2 nd stage of labor in a patient with severe anemia Cut short with forceps (Especially in this scenario as she is preterm – vacuum is contraindicated in preterm. Also, forceps is preferred in scenarios where the woman should not bear down as vacuum requires additional bearing down efforts).

questions.text: A couple went for pre-conceptional counseling and was detected to be anemic. On investigation, they were both found to have beta thalassemia minor. The chance their fetus will have thalassemia major is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 25%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta Thalassemia major is an autosomal recessive condition in which both the beta globin genes are defective and no beta chains are produced If the mother has thalassemia trait (beta thalassemia minor), the father’s status is checked. If the father also has the beta thalassemia trait, there is a 25% (1 in 4 chance) the fetus has beta thalassemia major. Prenatal diagnosis is done by Chorionic villous sampling in the 1 st trimester OR Amniocentesis in the 2 nd trimester
  • ➤ Beta Thalassemia major is an autosomal recessive condition in which both the beta globin genes are defective and no beta chains are produced

  • ➤ Prenatal diagnosis is done by Chorionic villous sampling in the 1 st trimester OR Amniocentesis in the 2 nd trimester
  • ➤ Chorionic villous sampling in the 1 st trimester OR Amniocentesis in the 2 nd trimester

questions.text: The single best test to diagnose iron deficiency anemia in pregnancy is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Serum ferritin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The single best test to diagnose iron deficiency anemia is serum ferritin Serum ferritin is a high molecular weight glycoprotein Normal concentration is 15 – 300 mcg/ L It is the single indicator of iron deficiency Levels < 30 mcg/ L show iron deficiency anemia with a 90% sensitivity and a 85% specificity It is unaffected by recent iron intake and is the first abnormal laboratory test in iron deficiency anemia
  • ➤ The single best test to diagnose iron deficiency anemia is serum ferritin
  • ➤ Serum ferritin is a high molecular weight glycoprotein
  • ➤ Normal concentration is 15 – 300 mcg/ L
  • ➤ It is the single indicator of iron deficiency
  • ➤ Levels < 30 mcg/ L show iron deficiency anemia with a 90% sensitivity and a 85% specificity
  • ➤ It is unaffected by recent iron intake and is the first abnormal laboratory test in iron deficiency anemia

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Page no 486, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 1 st edition

questions.text: A 29 y G3P2 presents to the antenatal OPD with severe anemia. On evaluation, she is found to have iron deficiency anemia. Which will not be seen in her investigations?
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron deficiency anemia is common in pregnancy; It is characterized by the following reports:
  • ➤ Iron deficiency anemia is common in pregnancy; It is characterized by the following reports:
  • ➤ Reduced MCV, MCH and MCHC Low serum iron Low serum ferritin (1 st test to be abnormal) Low transferrin saturation (10% or less) Raised free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP > 50) Raised Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) Raised serum transferrin receptor levels.
  • ➤ Reduced MCV, MCH and MCHC
  • ➤ Low serum iron
  • ➤ Low serum ferritin (1 st test to be abnormal)
  • ➤ Low transferrin saturation (10% or less)
  • ➤ Raised free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP > 50)
  • ➤ Raised Total iron binding capacity (TIBC)
  • ➤ Raised serum transferrin receptor levels.

questions.text: A 34y G2 is diagnosed to have anemia during her routine prenatal visits. She is started on oral iron but is unable to tolerate it. As per Anemia Mukt Bharat strategy, which parenteral preparations of iron is recommended for treatment of iron deficiency anemia?
questions.correct_answer: C. Iron Sucrose and iron Carboxymaltose
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Iron Sucrose and Iron Carboxymaltose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As per Anemia Mukt Bharat strategy, the following is recommended as first line strategy for treatment of anemia
  • ➤ As per Anemia Mukt Bharat strategy, the following is recommended as first line strategy for treatment of anemia
  • ➤ For mild anemia (10 – 10.9 g%) Two tablets of Iron and Folic Acid tablet (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by the health provider during the ANC contact. Parental iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose (FCM) may be considered as the first line of management in pregnant women who are detected to be anemic late in pregnancy or in whom compliance is likely to be low (high chance of lost to follow-up) Follow up every 2 monthly Once Hb is at the normal level, continue with prophylactic dose For moderate anemia (7 – 9.9 g%) Two tablets of Iron and Folic Acid tablet (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by the health provider during the ANC contact Parental iron (IV Iron Sucrose or FCM) may be considered as the first line of management in pregnant women who are detected to be anemic late in pregnancy or in whom compliance is likely to be low (high chance of lost to follow-up) If no improvement in haemoglobin (<1 g/dl increase) after two months of treatment, refer to First Referral Unit (FRU)/District Hospital (DH) by health provider For severe anemia (5 – 6.9 g%) Management of severe anemia in pregnant women will be done by the medical officer at PHC/CHC/FRU/DH The treatment will be done using IV Iron Sucrose/Ferric Carboxy Maltose (FCM) by the medical officer Immediate hospitalization recommended in the third trimester of pregnancy at a health facility where round-the-clock specialist care is available

questions.text: A 23-year G2 is detected to have asymptomatic bacteriuria at 16 weeks. If left untreated, what is her risk of developing symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 25%

Explanation:

  • • Explanation

Eradication of bacteriuria with antimicrobial agents prevents most of these. The American Academy of Pediatrics and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2017), as well as the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (2019), recommend screening for bacteriuria at the first prenatal visit

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman presents with new onset hypertension, proteinuria, and elevated serum creatinine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Preeclampsia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B: CKD is characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. While patients with CKD can present with hypertension, proteinuria, and elevated serum creatinine, the history of pregnancy and the acute presentation make preeclampsia a more likely diagnosis in this case.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Acute Pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection of the kidneys that can cause flank pain, fever, nausea, vomiting, and urinary symptoms, in addition to elevated serum creatinine and sometimes proteinuria. However, the key distinguishing feature of acute pyelonephritis is usually a fever and signs of infection, which are not mentioned in the scenario.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Glomerulonephritis is an inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys. It can cause hypertension, proteinuria, and elevated serum creatinine. However, in the context of pregnancy, especially without a prior history of renal disease, preeclampsia is a more common cause of these symptoms.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Preeclampsia is defined as Hypertension with Proteinuria in pregnancy
  • ➤ Blood pressure criteria includes systolic BP ≥ 140 mmHg or diastolic BP ≥ 90mmHg or both on 2 occasions at least 4h apart after 20 weeks gestation with previously normal BP Proteinuria is defined as a 24h urine collection > 300mg protein OR single voided urine protein/ creatinine ration ≥ 0.3 Or dipstick reading of 2 + (Recent ACOG guidelines).
  • ➤ Blood pressure criteria includes systolic BP ≥ 140 mmHg or diastolic BP ≥ 90mmHg or both on 2 occasions at least 4h apart after 20 weeks gestation with previously normal BP
  • ➤ Proteinuria is defined as a 24h urine collection > 300mg protein OR single voided urine protein/ creatinine ration ≥ 0.3 Or dipstick reading of 2 + (Recent ACOG guidelines).
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 720
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 720

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester presents with jaundice, fatigue, and elevated liver enzymes. She reports a recent history of consuming seafood at a local restaurant. Which type of viral hepatitis is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hepatitis A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B, C and D: Hepatitis B and C are more commonly transmitted through blood and bodily fluids, and while they can cause similar symptoms, the patient's history makes them less likely in this case. Hepatitis E, also transmitted feco-orally and linked to contaminated water, is a consideration, but Hepatitis A is more commonly associated with seafood consumption
  • • Option B, C and D:
  • • Pregnant women, especially those in the second or third trimester, are at a higher risk of developing severe disease if they contract Hepatitis E. The infection can lead to fulminant hepatic failure, a life-threatening condition characterized by rapid deterioration of liver function. The mortality rate for pregnant women with Hepatitis E, particularly in the third trimester, can be significantly higher than in the general population. Hepatitis E is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route, typically via contaminated water.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis A is typically transmitted via the fecal-oral route, often through contaminated food or water. The recent history of consuming seafood, a common vehicle for Hepatitis A transmission, along with the presentation of jaundice, fatigue, and elevated liver enzymes, strongly suggests Hepatitis
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition Pg 1062
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition Pg 1062

questions.text: Obstetric causes of Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) in pregnancy include except:
Which of the following is a recommended management strategy for a pregnant woman with chronic kidney disease (CKD)?

options.label: C
options.text: Close monitoring of renal function and blood pressure

questions.correct_answer: C. Close monitoring of renal function and blood pressure
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Close monitoring of renal function and blood pressure

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Discontinuation of all antihypertensive medications is not recommended. Many women with CKD require antihypertensive medications to control their blood pressure, which is crucial in preventing further renal damage and managing complications like preeclampsia. However, the choice of antihypertensive medication may need to be adjusted due to pregnancy, as some medications are contraindicated or not preferred during pregnancy.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Strict protein restriction: This approach is controversial and not generally recommended during pregnancy. While protein restriction can sometimes be beneficial in non-pregnant CKD patients to slow disease progression, during pregnancy, adequate protein intake is essential for fetal growth and development. Dietary modifications in pregnant CKD patients should be individualized and carefully balanced.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: Starting or continuing dialysis in a pregnant woman with CKD depends on the severity of the renal impairment and is not routinely initiated based solely on the presence of CKD. Dialysis is typically reserved for those with advanced kidney failure or when there are indications such as refractory fluid overload, severe uremia, or life-threatening electrolyte imbalances.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prenatal care for women with CKD incorporates several important aspects.
  • ➤ Frequent monitoring of blood pressure is paramount, and serum creatinine levels and 24-hour protein excretion are quantified as indicated. Bacteriuria is treated to lower the risk of pyelonephritis and further nephron loss. Protein-restricted diets are not recommended. In some women with anemia from chronic renal insufficiency, a response is seen with recombinant erythropoietin. Serial sonography is performed to follow fetal growth. The differentiation between worsening hypertension and superimposed pre-eclampsia is problematic. Angiogenic biomarkers placental growth factor (PlGF) and its soluble receptor, soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1), may be useful to separate chronic from gestational hypertension
  • ➤ Frequent monitoring of blood pressure is paramount, and serum creatinine levels and 24-hour protein excretion are quantified as indicated.
  • ➤ Bacteriuria is treated to lower the risk of pyelonephritis and further nephron loss.
  • ➤ Protein-restricted diets are not recommended.
  • ➤ In some women with anemia from chronic renal insufficiency, a response is seen with recombinant erythropoietin.
  • ➤ Serial sonography is performed to follow fetal growth.
  • ➤ The differentiation between worsening hypertension and superimposed pre-eclampsia is problematic. Angiogenic biomarkers placental growth factor (PlGF) and its soluble receptor, soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1), may be useful to separate chronic from gestational hypertension
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 26 th edition pg 2614

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no prior history of renal disease develops sudden onset of flank pain and hematuria in her second trimester. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B. Renal calculus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A: Acute cystitis is an infection of the bladder that often presents with symptoms like urinary frequency, urgency, dysuria (painful urination), and suprapubic pain. Hematuria can sometimes be present, but acute cystitis typically does not cause flank pain. Flank pain is more characteristic of upper urinary tract infections or obstructions, such as pyelonephritis or renal stones.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option C: Acute Pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection of the kidneys and is a more severe form of urinary tract infection. While it can cause flank pain and hematuria, it typically also presents with fever, chills, and other systemic symptoms such as nausea and vomiting. The sudden onset of severe pain is more characteristic of renal calculus than acute pyelonephritis, which often has a more gradual onset.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Glomerulonephritis is an inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys. It can present with hematuria, proteinuria, and sometimes hypertension. However, it is less likely to cause sudden onset flank pain.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sudden onset flank pain and hematuria in a pregnant woman with no prior renal disease history are suggestive of a renal calculus (kidney stone). Pregnancy increases the risk of kidney stones due to changes in urinary tract physiology.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg1030
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg1030

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of congenital heart disease presents for her first prenatal visit. Which of the following is the most important initial evaluation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Echocardiogram

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: 24-hour Holter Monitoring records the electrical activity of the heart over a 24-hour period using a portable device. It's useful for detecting arrhythmias (abnormal heart rhythms) that may not be captured during a brief ECG. However, while helpful in certain contexts, it does not provide information about the heart's structure or function, which is crucial in assessing congenital heart disease. Option C: Cardiac MRI provides detailed images of the heart's structure and function and can be used for complex congenital heart disease evaluation. However, its use in pregnancy is generally limited due to concerns about the potential effects of the strong magnetic field and contrast agents on the fetus. Therefore, it is not the first-line diagnostic tool in pregnant women unless specifically indicated and after careful consideration of the risks and benefits. Option D: Treadmill Stress Test assesses the heart's response to physical stress and is typically used to diagnose and evaluate coronary artery disease. It involves monitoring the heart while the patient walks on a treadmill with increasing speed and incline. However, it is not the primary tool for evaluating congenital heart disease and is less practical in pregnancy due to physical limitations and the risk of inducing stress on the cardiovascular system.
  • • Option A: 24-hour Holter Monitoring records the electrical activity of the heart over a 24-hour period using a portable device. It's useful for detecting arrhythmias (abnormal heart rhythms) that may not be captured during a brief ECG. However, while helpful in certain contexts, it does not provide information about the heart's structure or function, which is crucial in assessing congenital heart disease.

However, its use in pregnancy is generally limited due to concerns about the potential effects of the strong magnetic field and contrast agents on the fetus. Therefore, it is not the first-line diagnostic tool in pregnant women unless specifically indicated and after careful consideration of the risks and benefits.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Treadmill Stress Test assesses the heart's response to physical stress and is typically used to diagnose and evaluate coronary artery disease. It involves monitoring the heart while the patient walks on a treadmill with increasing speed and incline. However, it is not the primary tool for evaluating congenital heart disease and is less practical in pregnancy due to physical limitations and the risk of inducing stress on the cardiovascular system.
  • • Option D:

  • ➤ The most appropriate and important initial evaluation for a pregnant woman with a history of congenital heart disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with no prior medical history suddenly develops dyspnea and chest pain at 32 weeks gestation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Pulmonary embolism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: While symptoms of an anxiety attack can mimic those of more serious conditions (like shortness of breath and chest pain), the sudden onset of these symptoms in a pregnant woman, particularly in the third trimester, warrants a thorough evaluation for more serious conditions first. Anxiety should be considered a diagnosis of exclusion in this context. Option B: Peripartum Cardiomyopathy is a form of heart failure that occurs during the last month of pregnancy or within five months after delivery. Symptoms include dyspnea, fatigue, and swelling in the legs and feet. It typically does not present suddenly but rather develops gradually.
  • • Option A: While symptoms of an anxiety attack can mimic those of more serious conditions (like shortness of breath and chest pain), the sudden onset of these symptoms in a pregnant woman, particularly in the third trimester, warrants a thorough evaluation for more serious conditions first. Anxiety should be considered a diagnosis of exclusion in this context.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Peripartum Cardiomyopathy is a form of heart failure that occurs during the last month of pregnancy or within five months after delivery. Symptoms include dyspnea, fatigue, and swelling in the legs and feet. It typically does not present suddenly but rather develops gradually.
  • • Option B:
  • • Given the acute onset of dyspnea and chest pain in a pregnant woman in her third trimester, pulmonary embolism (Option C) should be considered the most likely diagnosis and warrants immediate medical evaluation due to its potentially life-threatening nature. Top of Form

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulmonary Embolism in Pregnancy:
  • ➤ Pulmonary Embolism in Pregnancy:
  • ➤ Causes 10% of maternal deaths in the developed world; up to 70% will have evidence of DVT Clinical Presentation: Symptoms : Dyspnea (most common symptom), chest pain, cough, syncope and hemoptysis Signs : Tachypnea, tachycardia. In some cases, an accentuated pulmonic closure sound, rales, and/or friction rub is heard. ECG : Right axis deviation and T-wave inversion in the anterior chest leads Chest X Ray: may be normal or nonspecific findings of atelectasis, an infiltrate, cardiomegaly, or an effusion. Vascular markings in the lung region supplied by the obstructed artery can be lost. ECHO : Echocardiography is useful to detect other conditions that mimic pulmonary embolism—acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection. Diagnostic Tests: the American Society of Hematology recommends ventilation perfusion lung scanning as the first-line diagnostic tool. Other guidelines prefer CT-pulmonary angiography for suspected pulmonary embolism Management: Anti coagulation with heparin Vena caval filter may be required Prior to cesarean (As anti-coagulation may lead to torrential surgical hemorrhage) If thrombolysis fails.
  • ➤ Causes 10% of maternal deaths in the developed world; up to 70% will have evidence of DVT

  • ➤ Symptoms : Dyspnea (most common symptom), chest pain, cough, syncope and hemoptysis Signs : Tachypnea, tachycardia. In some cases, an accentuated pulmonic closure sound, rales, and/or friction rub is heard.

questions.text: Which heart condition is most associated with a high risk of mortality in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Eisenmenger syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A: Mitral Valve Prolapse is a condition in which the mitral valve leaflets bulge (prolapse) into the left atrium during the heart's contraction. Most women with mitral valve prolapse have a mild form and can go through pregnancy without significant complications. Option B: An atrial septal defect (ASD) is a hole in the wall between the two upper chambers of the heart. If it has been repaired, the risk of complications during pregnancy is relatively low, especially if the repair was successful and there are no residual cardiac issues. Option D: Aortic stenosis involves narrowing of the aortic valve, which can impede blood flow from the heart to the aorta and onward to the rest of the body. If the aortic stenosis is mild to moderate and stable, most women can tolerate pregnancy well. However, severe aortic stenosis can be risky during pregnancy, although not as high-risk as Eisenmenger syndrome.
  • • Option A: Mitral Valve Prolapse is a condition in which the mitral valve leaflets bulge (prolapse) into the left atrium during the heart's contraction. Most women with mitral valve prolapse have a mild form and can go through pregnancy without significant complications.

  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: Aortic stenosis involves narrowing of the aortic valve, which can impede blood flow from the heart to the aorta and onward to the rest of the body. If the aortic stenosis is mild to moderate and stable, most women can tolerate pregnancy well. However, severe aortic stenosis can be risky during pregnancy, although not as high-risk as Eisenmenger syndrome.
  • • Option D:
  • • Among these options, Eisenmenger syndrome (Option C) is the one most associated with a high risk of mortality in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of rheumatic heart disease presents in her second trimester. Which of the following findings would most warrant intervention?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Mitral stenosis with symptoms

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Mitral stenosis, which involves narrowing of the mitral valve, restricts blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle. When symptomatic, it can lead to reduced cardiac output, pulmonary congestion, and even heart failure. Pregnancy increases the blood volume and heart rate, which can exacerbate these symptoms and complications. Severe symptomatic mitral stenosis often requires medical or even surgical intervention to manage the increased hemodynamic burden and to reduce the risk of maternal and fetal complications.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A: Mild mitral regurgitation, especially in the absence of symptoms, is usually well-tolerated during pregnancy and often does not require intervention. Pregnancy can increase the volume load on the heart, but mild regurgitation typically doesn't pose a significant risk. Option C: Trivial or mild aortic regurgitation typically does not pose a significant risk during pregnancy and often does not require intervention. The aortic valve allows blood to flow from the left ventricle to the aorta. If the regurgitation is only trivial, the heart can usually compensate well Option D: A small ASD, a hole in the septum between the heart's two upper chambers (atria), often does not significantly impact hemodynamics, especially if there is no evidence of right heart overload or pulmonary hypertension. In most cases, a small ASD does not require intervention during pregnancy and is generally well-tolerated.
  • • Option A: Mild mitral regurgitation, especially in the absence of symptoms, is usually well-tolerated during pregnancy and often does not require intervention. Pregnancy can increase the volume load on the heart, but mild regurgitation typically doesn't pose a significant risk.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option C: Trivial or mild aortic regurgitation typically does not pose a significant risk during pregnancy and often does not require intervention. The aortic valve allows blood to flow from the left ventricle to the aorta. If the regurgitation is only trivial, the heart can usually compensate well
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: A small ASD, a hole in the septum between the heart's two upper chambers (atria), often does not significantly impact hemodynamics, especially if there is no evidence of right heart overload or pulmonary hypertension. In most cases, a small ASD does not require intervention during pregnancy and is generally well-tolerated.
  • • Option D:
  • • Among these options, severe mitral stenosis with symptoms (Option B) is the finding that most warrants intervention.

questions.correct_answer: C. Monitor serum levels of antiepileptic drugs and adjust dosage accordingly
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Monitor serum levels of antiepileptic drugs and adjust dosage accordingly

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pregnancy can alter the metabolism and serum levels of antiepileptic drugs, potentially necessitating dosage adjustments. Monitoring serum levels and adjusting the dosage can help control seizures without excessively increasing medication levels.

Also ideally, the dose should be calculated based on monitoring serum levels of the drug and then adjusting the dose. Switching to a different class of a drug should not be done during pregnancy as it can lead to increased seizure risk

questions.text: Which of the following antiepileptic drugs is most associated with teratogenicity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Valproate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Valproate is strongly associated with teratogenicity and is generally avoided during pregnancy unless absolutely necessary. The defects can include neural tube defects, craniofacial defects, cardiovascular malformations, and limb defects. Due to these risks, valproate is generally avoided in women of childbearing age and during pregnancy unless there are no suitable alternatives.
  • • Valproate is strongly associated with teratogenicity and is generally avoided during pregnancy unless absolutely necessary. The defects can include neural tube defects, craniofacial defects, cardiovascular malformations, and limb defects. Due to these risks, valproate is generally avoided in women of childbearing age and during pregnancy unless there are no suitable alternatives.
  • • Other options :
  • • Other options
  • • Lamotrigine is generally considered one of the safer antiepileptic drugs during pregnancy. While there is some risk of teratogenicity with any antiepileptic drug, the risk with lamotrigine is relatively low compared to others, particularly valproate. Like lamotrigine, levetiracetam is also considered to be relatively safe in pregnancy. Gabapentin is less commonly associated with teratogenicity than valproate, but it is not considered as safe as lamotrigine or levetiracetam. Gabapentin may be used in pregnancy when the benefits outweigh the risks, but it is not the first choice.

questions.text: What is the initial recommended management for a pregnant woman with epilepsy who has a seizure?

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • If a pregnant woman with epilepsy has a seizure, the priority is to prevent injury and maintain oxygenation. Placing her in the left lateral decubitus position helps maintain uterine perfusion and prevent supine hypotension, while ensuring airway management is crucial.

Immediate discontinuation of antiepileptic drugs (Option D) is not recommended as it can increase the risk of further seizures.

  • • PTU is preferred in the first trimester due to the teratogenic risk of methimazole Propylthiouracil (PTU) has been historically preferred because it partially inhibits the conversion of T4 to T3 and crosses the placenta less readily than methimazole. Methimazole Is associated with a rare methimazole embryopathy, characterized by: Esophageal or choanal atresia Aplasia cutis, a congenital skin defect. However, treatment with PTU is associated with a higher risk for liver injury The American Thyroid Association and the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (2011) recommend PTU therapy during the first trimester followed by a switch to methimazole beginning in the second trimester. More recently, the American Thyroid Association recommends PTU therapy through 16 weeks’ gestation but does not make a recommendation regarding switching to methimazole treatment because both agents are associated with adverse effects and the harm from poorer control during the switch is unknown but the better answer to this question is to start with PTU and then switch to methimazole. Transient leukopenia can be documented in up to 10 percent of women taking antithyroid drugs, but this does not require therapy cessation. If fever or sore throat develops, women are instructed to discontinue medication immediately and report for a complete blood count

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in her second trimester of pregnancy has a normal TSH but elevated free T4 levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Subclinical hyperthyroidism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A: Subclinical Hypothyroidism is characterized by a mildly elevated TSH level with normal free T4 levels. It indicates a mild form of hypothyroidism where the thyroid is beginning to underperform but has not yet resulted in decreased thyroid hormone production. This option does not align with the patient's lab results, which show a normal TSH and elevated free T4.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Overt hypothyroidism is diagnosed when both TSH levels are high, and free T4 levels are low. This condition indicates a significant deficiency in thyroid hormone production. The patient's lab results do not support this diagnosis since her free T4 levels are elevated, not low.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: In overt hyperthyroidism, both TSH levels are suppressed (usually below the normal range), and free T4 levels are elevated. This condition indicates a significantly overactive thyroid. The patient's normal TSH level makes this diagnosis less likely compared to subclinical hyperthyroidism.
  • • Option C:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Normal TSH with elevated free T4 suggests subclinical hyperthyroidism (Option C), where the thyroid is overactive but not enough to suppress TSH. Overt hyperthyroidism (Option D) would typically present with a suppressed TSH.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1122, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1122, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: During pregnancy, a woman with no prior history of thyroid disease presents with a low TSH but normal free T4 and free T3 levels. What is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Gestational transient thyrotoxicosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Primary Hypothyroidism is characterized by high TSH levels and low free T4 levels, as the primary problem lies in the thyroid gland itself, which is unable to produce sufficient thyroid hormones. This diagnosis does not fit the patient's lab results, which show a low TSH level.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: In secondary hypothyroidism, both TSH and free T4 levels are low. This condition is due to a problem in the pituitary gland, which fails to produce enough TSH to stimulate the thyroid. Again, this option does not align with the patient's lab results, as her free T4 and T3 levels are normal.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: While hyperemesis gravidarum, a condition characterized by severe nausea and vomiting in pregnancy, can be associated with thyroid function changes, it typically does not cause isolated low TSH with normal free T4 and T3 levels. The thyroid function changes seen in hyperemesis gravidarum are usually a part of gestational transient thyrotoxicosis.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gestational Transient Thyrotoxicosis is characterized by transiently low TSH levels in the first trimester of pregnancy, usually due to the high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which can stimulate the thyroid gland. It typically occurs without significant thyroid dysfunction, and free T4 and free T3 levels remain within normal limits. This condition is usually self-limiting and resolves as pregnancy progresses.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1122, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1122, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman in her first trimester presents with fever, rash, and arthralgia. She recently returned from a trip to a region where Zika virus is endemic. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Order Zika virus testing

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zika virus in pregnancy
  • ➤ Zika virus in pregnancy
  • ➤ This RNA flavivirus is the first major mosquito-borne teratogen recognized Zika virus is primarily transmitted by mosquito bite, but sexual transmission is possible. Maternal-Fetal Infection: Zika infection is asymptomatic in approximately 80 percent of adults. It may cause mild rash, fever, headache, arthralgia, and conjunctivitis lasting a few days. The fetus can be severely infected whether the mother is symptomatic. In the most severely affected fetuses, a congenital Zika syndrome has been described that includes microcephaly, lissencephaly, ventriculomegaly, intracranial calcifications, ocular abnormalities, and congenital contractures Diagnosis and Management. Laboratory testing for Zika infection is recommended in symptomatic gravidas with residence in or recent travel to areas with active dengue transmission and risk for Zika transmission Serum IgM antibodies typically become detectable within the first 2 weeks and may persist for months. For a pregnant woman within 12 weeks of symptom onset, PCR testing of serum and urine specimens for both dengue and Zika virus RNA is recommended. For women with prenatal ultrasound findings suggesting congenital Zika syndrome, Zika virus PCR and IgM are initially performed on serum and urine. Amnionic fluid PCR may be performed, although less is known about its diagnostic accuracy for congenital infection. Currently, no specific treatment or vaccine is available for Zika infection, although several vaccines are in development
